title: Module 1: Networking Today - What is a Network?
note: Introduce the concept of a network, its purpose, and the different types of networks (LAN, WAN, SOHO).

title: Role of Routers and Switches
note: Explain the fundamental roles of routers (forwarding packets between different networks, Layer 3) and switches (forwarding frames within a single network, Layer 2).

title: Next-Generation Firewalls and Access Points
note: Introduce other key network components: Next-Generation Firewalls (NGFW) for security and Access Points (APs) for wireless connectivity.

title: Two-Tier and Three-Tier Architectures
note: Compare and contrast the traditional three-tier (core, distribution, access) and two-tier (collapsed core) hierarchical network design models.

title: Spine-Leaf Architecture
note: Introduce the modern spine-leaf architecture used in data centers, explaining its advantages for scalability and low latency.

title: Cabling: Copper (Cat5e, Cat6)
note: Cover twisted-pair copper cabling standards. Explain the differences between Cat 5e and Cat 6, and concepts like straight-through vs. crossover cables.

title: Cabling: Fiber Optic
note: Explain fiber optic cabling. Differentiate between single-mode (long distance) and multi-mode (shorter distance) fiber.

title: Troubleshooting Physical Layer Issues
note: Discuss how to identify and troubleshoot common physical layer issues, such as duplex mismatches, collisions, and speed negotiation problems.

title: Module 2: TCP/IP - The TCP/IP Model
note: Introduce the four-layer TCP/IP model (Application, Transport, Internet, Network Access) and compare it to the seven-layer OSI model.

title: TCP vs. UDP
note: Compare TCP (connection-oriented, reliable) and UDP (connectionless, best-effort). Explain the TCP three-way handshake.

title: Binary Numbering
note: Teach how to convert decimal numbers to binary and back, a foundational skill for IP addressing.

title: Hexadecimal Numbering
note: Teach how to convert between binary, hexadecimal, and decimal, focusing on its use in IPv6 and MAC addresses.

title: IPv4 Address Structure
note: Break down the 32-bit IPv4 address into its network and host portions. Explain the concept of the subnet mask.

title: IPv4 Address Classes and Private Ranges
note: Explain the historical IP address classes (A, B, C) and define the private IP address ranges specified in RFC 1918.

title: IPv4 Subnetting
note: Provide a step-by-step guide to subnetting an IPv4 network to create smaller, more manageable subnets.

title: Variable Length Subnet Masking (VLSM)
note: Introduce VLSM as a technique to use different subnet masks for different subnets, which conserves IP address space.

title: IPv6 Address Structure and Types
note: Explain the 128-bit IPv6 address format, hexadecimal notation, and abbreviation rules. Cover address types like global unicast, unique local, and link-local.

title: IPv6 Address Configuration (SLAAC and DHCPv6)
note: Explain the two main methods for IPv6 address autoconfiguration: SLAAC (Stateless Address Autoconfiguration) and stateful DHCPv6.

title: Module 3: Switching - MAC Addresses
note: Explain the structure and purpose of a MAC address. Describe how switches use MAC addresses to forward frames at Layer 2.

title: The MAC Address Table
note: Explain how a switch builds its MAC address table by learning the source MAC addresses of frames that enter its ports.

title: Introduction to VLANs
note: Introduce Virtual LANs (VLANs) as a mechanism to logically segment a physical network into separate broadcast domains.

title: Configuring VLANs and Access Ports
note: Demonstrate how to create VLANs on a Cisco switch and assign switch ports to a specific VLAN as access ports.

title: VLAN Trunking with 802.1Q
note: Explain the IEEE 802.1Q trunking protocol for passing traffic for multiple VLANs between switches. Demonstrate trunk port configuration.

title: Dynamic Trunking Protocol (DTP)
note: Introduce DTP as a Cisco-proprietary protocol for automatically negotiating trunk links. Discuss its different modes.

title: EtherChannel (LACP and PAgP)
note: Cover EtherChannel for bundling multiple physical links into a single logical link. Explain the LACP (open standard) and PAgP (Cisco proprietary) negotiation protocols.

title: Spanning Tree Protocol (STP)
note: Introduce STP (802.1D) as a protocol that prevents Layer 2 loops in networks with redundant switch links. Explain the election of a root bridge and port roles.

title: Module 4: Routing - The Routing Table
note: Explain how a router makes forwarding decisions. Cover how to read a routing table, including route source, administrative distance, and metric.

title: Static Routing
note: Demonstrate the configuration of IPv4 and IPv6 static routes, including default routes ('gateway of last resort').

title: Inter-VLAN Routing
note: Explain the need for a router or Layer 3 switch to enable communication between different VLANs. Introduce the 'Router on a Stick' configuration.

title: Introduction to OSPFv2
note: Introduce OSPF as a dynamic routing protocol. Explain neighbor adjacencies, router IDs, areas, and the cost metric.

title: Configuring Single-Area OSPFv2
note: Provide a practical guide to configuring and verifying single-area OSPFv2, including network statements and `show` commands.

title: Module 5: IP Services - Network Address Translation (NAT)
note: Explain the purpose of NAT. Differentiate between static NAT, dynamic NAT, and Port Address Translation (PAT).

title: Network Time Protocol (NTP)
note: Cover NTP for synchronizing clocks. Demonstrate how to configure a Cisco device as an NTP client.

title: Dynamic Host Configuration Protocol (DHCP)
note: Explain the DORA process. Demonstrate how to configure a Cisco router to act as a DHCP server.

title: Domain Name System (DNS)
note: Explain the role of DNS in translating domain names to IP addresses. Cover how to configure DNS servers on a client device.

title: Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP)
note: Provide an overview of SNMP for collecting information about managed devices on a network.

title: Module 6: Security - Access Control Lists (ACLs)
note: Introduce ACLs for filtering traffic. Explain the difference between standard and extended ACLs and the implicit 'deny any'.

title: Configuring Standard and Extended ACLs
note: Demonstrate how to configure numbered and named ACLs and apply them to router interfaces.

title: Port Security
note: Teach how to configure Port Security on a Cisco switch to limit the number of MAC addresses allowed on a port and prevent MAC address flooding.

title: DHCP Snooping
note: Explain how DHCP Snooping is used to prevent rogue DHCP servers from operating on the network.

title: Wireless LAN Security (WPA2/WPA3)
note: Cover securing wireless networks with WPA2 and WPA3. Demonstrate configuring Pre-Shared Key (PSK) authentication.

title: Module 7: Automation - REST APIs and JSON
note: Provide an overview of REST APIs and JSON as foundational technologies for modern network automation.

title: Configuration Management Tools
note: Provide a high-level overview of Ansible, Puppet, and Chef and their role in declarative network configuration.

title: Module 8: Final Project - Small Office Network
note: Outline the final project: design and configure a small office network in Cisco Packet Tracer, including a router, two switches, two VLANs, and basic security.

title: Final Project: Network Design and IP Addressing
note: Create a network diagram and an IP addressing scheme for the final project network.

title: Final Project: Basic Device Configuration
note: Perform initial device configuration, including hostnames, passwords, and management IP addresses.

title: Final Project: VLANs and Trunking
note: Configure two VLANs (e.g., Sales and Engineering) and set up an 802.1Q trunk between the two switches.

title: Final Project: Inter-VLAN Routing
note: Configure 'Router on a Stick' on the router to enable communication between the two VLANs.

title: Final Project: Security Configuration
note: Implement a basic ACL to restrict traffic between the VLANs and configure Port Security on the switches.

title: Module 9: Further Reading
note: Provide links to the official Cisco CCNA exam topics, recommended study guides, and online lab resources.
